sn41.6:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā kāmabhū macchikāsaṇḍe viharati ambāṭakavane.
sn41.6:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Kāmabhū was staying near Macchikāsaṇḍa in the Wild Mango Grove.

sn41.6:1.2.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati yenāyasmā kāmabhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho citto gahapati āyasmantaṃ kāmabhuṃ etadavoca:
sn41.6:1.2.eng: Then Citta the householder went up to Venerable Kāmabhū, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn41.6:1.5.eng: The physical process, the verbal process, and the mental process.”

sn41.6:1.6.pli: “Sādhu, bhante”ti kho citto gahapati āyasmato kāmabhussa bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā āyasmantaṃ kāmabhuṃ uttariṃ pañhaṃ apucchi:
sn41.6:1.6.eng: Saying “Good, sir,” Citta approved and agreed with what Kāmabhū said. Then he asked another question:

sn41.6:1.7.pli: “katamo pana, bhante, kāyasaṅkhāro, katamo vacīsaṅkhāro, katamo cittasaṅkhāro”ti?
sn41.6:1.7.eng: “But sir, what is the physical process? What’s the verbal process? What’s the mental process?”

sn41.6:1.8.pli: “Assāsapassāsā kho, gahapati, kāyasaṅkhāro, vitakkavicārā vacīsaṅkhāro, saññā ca vedanā ca cittasaṅkhāro”ti.
sn41.6:1.8.eng: “Breathing is a physical process. Placing the mind and keeping it connected are a verbal process. Perception and feeling are a mental process.”

sn41.6:2.1.pli: “Sādhu, bhante”ti kho citto gahapati …pe… uttariṃ pañhaṃ apucchi:
sn41.6:2.1.eng: Saying “Good, sir,” he asked another question:

sn41.6:2.2.pli: “kasmā pana, bhante, assāsapassāsā kāyasaṅkhāro, kasmā vitakkavicārā vacīsaṅkhāro, kasmā saññā ca vedanā ca cittasaṅkhāro”ti?
sn41.6:2.2.eng: “But sir, why is breathing a physical process? Why are placing the mind and keeping it connected a verbal process? Why are perception and feeling a mental process?”

sn41.6:2.3.pli: “Assāsapassāsā kho, gahapati, kāyikā. Ete dhammā kāyappaṭibaddhā, tasmā assāsapassāsā kāyasaṅkhāro.
sn41.6:2.3.eng: “Breathing is physical. It’s tied up with the body, that’s why breathing is a physical process.

sn41.6:2.4.pli: Pubbe kho, gahapati, vitakketvā vicāretvā pacchā vācaṃ bhindati, tasmā vitakkavicārā vacīsaṅkhāro.
sn41.6:2.4.eng: First you place the mind and keep it connected, then you break into speech. That’s why placing the mind and keeping it connected are a verbal process.

sn41.6:2.5.pli: Saññā ca vedanā ca cetasikā. Ete dhammā cittappaṭibaddhā, tasmā saññā ca vedanā ca cittasaṅkhāro”ti.
sn41.6:2.5.eng: Perception and feeling are mental. They’re tied up with the mind, that’s why perception and feeling are a mental process.”

sn41.6:3.1.eng: Saying “Good, sir,” he asked another question:

sn41.6:3.2.eng: “But sir, how does someone attain the cessation of perception and feeling?”

sn41.6:3.3.pli: “Na kho, gahapati, saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjantassa bhikkhuno evaṃ hoti:
sn41.6:3.3.eng: “A mendicant who is entering such an attainment does not think:

sn41.6:3.4.pli: ‘ahaṃ saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjissan’ti vā ‘ahaṃ saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjāmī’ti vā ‘ahaṃ saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpanno’ti vā.
sn41.6:3.4.eng: ‘I will enter the cessation of perception and feeling’ or ‘I am entering the cessation of perception and feeling’ or ‘I have entered the cessation of perception and feeling.’

sn41.6:3.5.pli: Atha khvassa pubbeva tathā cittaṃ bhāvitaṃ hoti yaṃ taṃ tathattāya upanetī”ti.
sn41.6:3.5.eng: Rather, their mind has been previously developed so as to lead to such a state.”

sn41.6:4.1.eng: Saying “Good, sir,” he asked another question:

sn41.6:4.2.pli: “saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjantassa pana, bhante, bhikkhuno katame dhammā paṭhamaṃ nirujjhanti, yadi vā kāyasaṅkhāro, yadi vā vacīsaṅkhāro, yadi vā cittasaṅkhāro”ti?
sn41.6:4.2.eng: “But sir, which cease first for a mendicant who is entering the cessation of perception and feeling: the physical, verbal, or mental process?”

sn41.6:4.3.pli: “Saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjantassa kho, gahapati, bhikkhuno vacīsaṅkhāro paṭhamaṃ nirujjhati, tato kāyasaṅkhāro, tato cittasaṅkhāro”ti.
sn41.6:4.3.eng: “The verbal process ceases first, then physical, then mental.”

sn41.6:5.1.eng: Saying “Good, sir,” he asked another question:

sn41.6:5.2.pli: “yvāyaṃ, bhante, mato kālaṅkato, yo cāyaṃ bhikkhu saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpanno, imesaṃ kiṃ nānākaraṇan”ti?
sn41.6:5.2.eng: “What’s the difference between someone who has passed away and a mendicant who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling?”

sn41.6:5.3.pli: “Yvāyaṃ, gahapati, mato kālaṅkato tassa kāyasaṅkhāro niruddho paṭippassaddho, vacīsaṅkhāro niruddho paṭippassaddho, cittasaṅkhāro niruddho paṭippassaddho, āyu parikkhīṇo, usmā vūpasantā, indriyāni viparibhinnāni.
sn41.6:5.3.eng: “When someone dies, their physical, verbal, and mental processes have ceased and stilled; their vitality is spent; their warmth is dissipated; and their faculties have disintegrated.

sn41.6:5.4.pli: Yo ca khvāyaṃ, gahapati, bhikkhu saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpanno, tassapi kāyasaṅkhāro niruddho paṭippassaddho, vacīsaṅkhāro niruddho paṭippassaddho, cittasaṅkhāro niruddho paṭippassaddho, āyu aparikkhīṇo, usmā avūpasantā, indriyāni vippasannāni.
sn41.6:5.4.eng: When a mendicant has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, their physical, verbal, and mental processes have ceased and stilled. But their vitality is not spent; their warmth is not dissipated; and their faculties are very clear.

sn41.6:5.5.pli: Yvāyaṃ, gahapati, mato kālaṅkato, yo cāyaṃ bhikkhu saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpanno, idaṃ nesaṃ nānākaraṇan”ti.
sn41.6:5.5.eng: That’s the difference between someone who has passed away and a mendicant who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling.”

sn41.6:6.1.eng: Saying “Good, sir,” he asked another question:

sn41.6:6.2.eng: “But sir, how does someone emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling?”

sn41.6:6.3.pli: “Na kho, gahapati, saññāvedayitanirodhasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhahantassa bhikkhuno evaṃ hoti:
sn41.6:6.3.eng: “A mendicant who is emerging from such an attainment does not think:

sn41.6:6.4.pli: ‘ahaṃ saññāvedayitanirodhasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhahissan’ti vā ‘ahaṃ saññāvedayitanirodhasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhahāmī’ti vā ‘ahaṃ saññāvedayitanirodhasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhito’ti vā.
sn41.6:6.4.eng: ‘I will emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling’ or ‘I am emerging from the cessation of perception and feeling’ or ‘I have emerged from the cessation of perception and feeling.’

sn41.6:6.5.pli: Atha khvassa pubbeva tathā cittaṃ bhāvitaṃ hoti, yaṃ taṃ tathattāya upanetī”ti.
sn41.6:6.5.eng: Rather, their mind has been previously developed so as to lead to such a state.”

sn41.6:7.1.eng: Saying “Good, sir,” he asked another question:

sn41.6:7.2.pli: “saññāvedayitanirodhasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhahantassa pana, bhante, bhikkhuno katame dhammā paṭhamaṃ uppajjanti, yadi vā kāyasaṅkhāro, yadi vā vacīsaṅkhāro, yadi vā cittasaṅkhāro”ti?
sn41.6:7.2.eng: “But sir, which arise first for a mendicant who is emerging from the cessation of perception and feeling: the physical, verbal, or mental process?”

sn41.6:7.3.pli: “Saññāvedayitanirodhasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhahantassa, gahapati, bhikkhuno cittasaṅkhāro paṭhamaṃ uppajjati, tato kāyasaṅkhāro, tato vacīsaṅkhāro”ti.
sn41.6:7.3.eng: “The mental process arises first, then physical, then verbal.”

sn41.6:8.1.eng: Saying “Good, sir,” he asked another question:

sn41.6:8.2.pli: “saññāvedayitanirodhasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhitaṃ pana, bhante, bhikkhuṃ kati phassā phusanti”?
sn41.6:8.2.eng: “But sir, when a mendicant has emerged from the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling, how many kinds of contact do they experience?”

sn41.6:8.3.pli: “Saññāvedayitanirodhasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhitaṃ kho, gahapati, bhikkhuṃ tayo phassā phusanti—

sn41.6:8.4.pli: suññato phasso, animitto phasso, appaṇihito phasso”ti.

sn41.6:9.1.eng: Saying “Good, sir,” he asked another question:

sn41.6:9.2.pli: “saññāvedayitanirodhasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhitassa pana, bhante, bhikkhuno kiṃninnaṃ cittaṃ hoti, kiṃpoṇaṃ, kiṃpabbhāran”ti?
sn41.6:9.2.eng: “But sir, when a mendicant has emerged from the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling, what does their mind slant, slope, and incline to?”

sn41.6:9.3.pli: “Saññāvedayitanirodhasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhitassa kho, gahapati, bhikkhuno vivekaninnaṃ cittaṃ hoti vivekapoṇaṃ vivekapabbhāran”ti.
sn41.6:9.3.eng: “Their mind slants, slopes, and inclines to seclusion.”

sn41.6:10.1.pli: “Sādhu, bhante”ti kho citto gahapati āyasmato kāmabhussa bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā āyasmantaṃ kāmabhuṃ uttariṃ pañhaṃ apucchi:
sn41.6:10.1.eng: Saying “Good, sir,” Citta approved and agreed with what Kāmabhū said. Then he asked another question:

sn41.6:10.2.eng: “But sir, how many things are helpful for attaining the cessation of perception and feeling?”

sn41.6:10.3.pli: “Addhā kho tvaṃ, gahapati, yaṃ paṭhamaṃ pucchitabbaṃ taṃ pucchasi.
sn41.6:10.3.eng: “Well, householder, you’ve finally asked what you should have asked first!

sn41.6:10.5.pli: Saññāvedayitanirodhasamāpattiyā kho, gahapati, dve dhammā bahūpakārā—
sn41.6:10.5.eng: Two things are helpful for attaining the cessation of perception and feeling:

sn41.7:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā godatto macchikāsaṇḍe viharati ambāṭakavane.
sn41.7:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Godatta was staying near Macchikāsaṇḍa in the Wild Mango Grove.

sn41.7:1.2.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati yenāyasmā godatto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ godattaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho cittaṃ gahapatiṃ āyasmā godatto etadavoca:
sn41.7:1.2.eng: Then Citta the householder went up to Venerable Godatta, bowed, and sat down to one side. Godatta said to him:

sn41.7:1.3.pli: “yā cāyaṃ, gahapati, appamāṇā cetovimutti, yā ca ākiñcaññā cetovimutti, yā ca suññatā cetovimutti, yā ca animittā cetovimutti, ime dhammā nānatthā nānābyañjanā udāhu ekatthā byañjanameva nānan”ti?
sn41.7:1.3.eng: “Householder, the limitless release of the heart, and the release of the heart through nothingness, and the release of the heart through emptiness, and the signless release of the heart: do these things differ in both meaning and phrasing? Or do they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?”

sn41.7:1.4.pli: “Atthi, bhante, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma ime dhammā nānatthā ceva nānābyañjanā ca.
sn41.7:1.4.eng: “Sir, there is a way in which these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.

sn41.7:1.5.pli: Atthi pana, bhante, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma ime dhammā ekatthā byañjanameva nānan”ti.
sn41.7:1.5.eng: But there’s also a way in which they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing.

sn41.7:2.1.pli: “Katamo ca, bhante, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma ime dhammā nānatthā ceva nānābyañjanā ca?
sn41.7:2.1.eng: And what’s the way in which these things differ in both meaning and phrasing?

sn41.7:2.2.pli: Idha, bhante, bhikkhu mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
sn41.7:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

sn41.7:2.3.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of compassion …

sn41.7:2.4.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing …

sn41.7:2.5.pli: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
sn41.7:2.5.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

sn41.7:2.6.eng: This is called the limitless release of the heart.

sn41.7:3.1.eng: And what is the release of the heart through nothingness?

sn41.7:3.2.pli: Idha, bhante, bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma, ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn41.7:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.

sn41.7:3.3.eng: This is called the release of the heart through nothingness.

sn41.7:4.1.eng: And what is the release of the heart through emptiness?

sn41.7:4.2.pli: Idha, bhante, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati:
sn41.7:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:

sn41.7:4.3.eng: ‘This is empty of a self or what belongs to a self.’

sn41.7:4.4.eng: This is called the release of the heart through emptiness.

sn41.7:5.1.eng: And what is the signless heart’s release?

sn41.7:5.2.pli: Idha, bhante, bhikkhu sabbanimittānaṃ amanasikārā animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn41.7:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, not focusing on any signs, enters and remains in the signless immersion of the heart.

sn41.7:5.3.eng: This is called the signless release of the heart.

sn41.7:5.4.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhante, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma ime dhammā nānatthā ceva nānābyañjanā ca.
sn41.7:5.4.eng: This is the way in which these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.

sn41.7:6.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhante, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma ime dhammā ekatthā byañjanameva nānaṃ?
sn41.7:6.1.eng: And what’s the way in which they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?

sn41.7:6.2.pli: Rāgo, bhante, pamāṇakaraṇo, doso pamāṇakaraṇo, moho pamāṇakaraṇo.
sn41.7:6.2.eng: Greed, hate, and delusion are makers of limits.

sn41.7:6.3.pli: Te khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
sn41.7:6.3.eng: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and obliterated them, so they are unable to arise in the future.

sn41.7:6.4.pli: Yāvatā kho, bhante, appamāṇā cetovimuttiyo, akuppā tāsaṃ cetovimutti aggamakkhāyati.
sn41.7:6.4.eng: The unshakable release of the heart is said to be the best kind of limitless release of the heart.

sn41.7:6.5.pli: Sā kho pana akuppā cetovimutti suññā rāgena, suññā dosena, suññā mohena.
sn41.7:6.5.eng: That unshakable release of the heart is empty of greed, hate, and delusion.

sn41.7:6.6.pli: Rāgo kho, bhante, kiñcanaṃ, doso kiñcanaṃ, moho kiñcanaṃ.
sn41.7:6.6.eng: Greed is something, hate is something, and delusion is something.

sn41.7:6.7.pli: Te khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
sn41.7:6.7.eng: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and obliterated them, so they are unable to arise in the future.

sn41.7:6.8.pli: Yāvatā kho, bhante, ākiñcaññā cetovimuttiyo, akuppā tāsaṃ cetovimutti aggamakkhāyati.
sn41.7:6.8.eng: The unshakable release of the heart is said to be the best kind of release of the heart through nothingness.

sn41.7:6.9.pli: Sā kho pana akuppā cetovimutti suññā rāgena, suññā dosena, suññā mohena.
sn41.7:6.9.eng: That unshakable release of the heart is empty of greed, hate, and delusion.

sn41.7:6.10.pli: Rāgo kho, bhante, nimittakaraṇo, doso nimittakaraṇo, moho nimittakaraṇo.
sn41.7:6.10.eng: Greed, hate, and delusion are makers of signs.

sn41.7:6.11.pli: Te khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
sn41.7:6.11.eng: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and obliterated them, so they are unable to arise in the future.

sn41.7:6.12.pli: Yāvatā kho, bhante, animittā cetovimuttiyo, akuppā tāsaṃ cetovimutti aggamakkhāyati.
sn41.7:6.12.eng: The unshakable release of the heart is said to be the best kind of signless release of the heart.

sn41.7:6.13.pli: Sā kho pana akuppā cetovimutti suññā rāgena, suññā dosena, suññā mohena.
sn41.7:6.13.eng: That unshakable release of the heart is empty of greed, hate, and delusion.

sn41.7:6.14.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhante, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma ime dhammā ekatthā byañjanameva nānan”ti.
sn41.7:6.14.eng: This is the way in which they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing.”

sn41.7:6.16.pli: Yassa te gambhīre buddhavacane paññācakkhu kamatī”ti.
sn41.7:6.16.eng: to traverse the Buddha’s deep teachings with the eye of wisdom.”

sn41.8:0.3.eng: The Jain Ascetic of the Ñātika Clan

sn41.8:1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto macchikāsaṇḍaṃ anuppatto hoti mahatiyā nigaṇṭhaparisāya saddhiṃ.
sn41.8:1.1.eng: Now at that time the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan had arrived at Macchikāsaṇḍa together with a large assembly of Jain ascetics.

sn41.8:1.2.pli: Assosi kho citto gahapati: “nigaṇṭho kira nāṭaputto macchikāsaṇḍaṃ anuppatto mahatiyā nigaṇṭhaparisāya saddhin”ti.
sn41.8:1.2.eng: Citta the householder heard that they had arrived.

sn41.8:1.3.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati sambahulehi upāsakehi saddhiṃ yena nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā nigaṇṭhena nāṭaputtena saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn41.8:1.3.eng: Together with several lay followers, he went up to the Jain Ñātika and exchanged greetings with him.

sn41.8:1.4.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho cittaṃ gahapatiṃ nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto etadavoca:
sn41.8:1.4.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. The Jain Ñātika said to him,

sn41.8:1.5.eng: “Householder, do you have faith in the ascetic Gotama’s claim that

sn41.8:1.6.pli: atthi avitakko avicāro samādhi, atthi vitakkavicārānaṃ nirodho”ti?
sn41.8:1.6.eng: there is a state of immersion without placing the mind and keeping it connected; that there is the cessation of placing the mind and keeping it connected?”

sn41.8:2.1.pli: “Na khvāhaṃ ettha, bhante, bhagavato saddhāya gacchāmi.
sn41.8:2.1.eng: “Sir, in this case I don’t rely on faith in the Buddha’s claim that

sn41.8:2.2.pli: Atthi avitakko avicāro samādhi, atthi vitakkavicārānaṃ nirodho”ti.
sn41.8:2.2.eng: there is a state of immersion without placing the mind and keeping it connected; that there is the cessation of placing the mind and keeping it connected.”

sn41.8:2.3.pli: Evaṃ vutte, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto ulloketvā etadavoca:
sn41.8:2.3.eng: When he said this, the Jain Ñātika looked up at his assembly and said,

sn41.8:2.4.pli: “idaṃ bhavanto passantu, yāva ujuko cāyaṃ citto gahapati, yāva asaṭho cāyaṃ citto gahapati, yāva amāyāvī cāyaṃ citto gahapati, vātaṃ vā so jālena bādhetabbaṃ maññeyya, yo vitakkavicāre nirodhetabbaṃ maññeyya, sakamuṭṭhinā vā so gaṅgāya sotaṃ āvāretabbaṃ maññeyya, yo vitakkavicāre nirodhetabbaṃ maññeyyā”ti.
sn41.8:2.4.eng: “See, good fellows, how straightforward this householder Citta is! He’s not devious or deceitful at all. To imagine that you can stop placing the mind and keeping it connected would be like imagining that you can catch the wind in a net, or dam the Ganges river with your own hand.”

sn41.8:3.2.pli: katamaṃ nu kho paṇītataraṃ—ñāṇaṃ vā saddhā vā”ti?

sn41.8:3.3.eng: “Knowledge is definitely better than faith, householder.”

sn41.8:3.4.pli: “Ahaṃ kho, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāmi, vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn41.8:3.4.eng: “Well sir, whenever I want, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn41.8:3.5.pli: Ahaṃ kho, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāmi, vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn41.8:3.5.eng: And whenever I want, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled … I enter and remain in the second absorption.

sn41.8:3.6.pli: Ahaṃ kho, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāmi, pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn41.8:3.6.eng: And whenever I want, with the fading away of rapture … I enter and remain in the third absorption.

sn41.8:3.7.pli: Ahaṃ kho, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāmi, sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn41.8:3.7.eng: And whenever I want, giving up pleasure and pain … I enter and remain in the fourth absorption.

sn41.8:3.8.pli: Na so khvāhaṃ, bhante, evaṃ jānanto evaṃ passanto kassa aññassa samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā saddhāya gamissāmi?
sn41.8:3.8.eng: And so, sir, since I know and see like this, why should I rely on faith in another ascetic or brahmin who claims that

sn41.8:3.9.pli: Atthi avitakko avicāro samādhi, atthi vitakkavicārānaṃ nirodho”ti.
sn41.8:3.9.eng: there is a state of immersion without placing the mind and keeping it connected; that there is the cessation of placing the mind and keeping it connected?”

sn41.8:4.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto sakaṃ parisaṃ apaloketvā etadavoca:
sn41.8:4.1.eng: When he said this, the Jain Ñātika looked askance at his own assembly and said,

sn41.8:4.2.pli: “idaṃ bhavanto passantu, yāva anujuko cāyaṃ citto gahapati, yāva saṭho cāyaṃ citto gahapati, yāva māyāvī cāyaṃ citto gahapatī”ti.
sn41.8:4.2.eng: “See, good fellows, how crooked this householder Citta is! He’s so devious and deceitful!”

sn41.8:5.1.eng: “Sir, just now I understood you to say:

sn41.8:5.2.pli: ‘evaṃ ājānāma idaṃ bhavanto passantu, yāva ujuko cāyaṃ citto gahapati, yāva asaṭho cāyaṃ citto gahapati, yāva amāyāvī cāyaṃ citto gahapatī’ti.
sn41.8:5.2.eng: ‘See, good fellows, how straightforward this householder Citta is! He’s not devious or deceitful at all.’

sn41.8:5.3.pli: Idāneva ca pana mayaṃ, bhante, bhāsitaṃ:
sn41.8:5.3.eng: But then I understood you to say:

sn41.8:5.4.pli: ‘evaṃ ājānāma idaṃ bhavanto passantu, yāva anujuko cāyaṃ citto gahapati, yāva saṭho cāyaṃ citto gahapati, yāva māyāvī cāyaṃ citto gahapatī’ti.
sn41.8:5.4.eng: ‘See, good fellows, how crooked this householder Citta is! He’s so devious and deceitful!’

sn41.8:5.5.pli: Sace te, bhante, purimaṃ saccaṃ, pacchimaṃ te micchā.
sn41.8:5.5.eng: If your first statement is true, the second is wrong.

sn41.8:5.6.pli: Sace pana te, bhante, purimaṃ micchā, pacchimaṃ te saccaṃ.
sn41.8:5.6.eng: If your first statement is wrong, the second is true.

sn41.8:5.7.pli: Ime kho pana, bhante, dasa sahadhammikā pañhā āgacchanti.
sn41.8:5.7.eng: And also, sir, these ten legitimate questions are relevant.

sn41.8:5.8.pli: Yadā nesaṃ atthaṃ ājāneyyāsi, atha maṃ paṭihareyyāsi saddhiṃ nigaṇṭhaparisāya.
sn41.8:5.8.eng: When you understand what they mean, then, together with your assembly of Jain ascetics, you can rebut me.

sn41.8:5.9.pli: Eko pañho, eko uddeso, ekaṃ veyyākaraṇaṃ.
sn41.8:5.9.eng: ‘One thing: question, summary, and answer. Two … three … four … five … six … seven … eight … nine … ten things: question, summary, and answer.’”

sn41.8:5.10.pli: Dve pañhā, dve uddesā, dve veyyākaraṇāni.

sn41.8:5.11.pli: Tayo pañhā, tayo uddesā, tīṇi veyyākaraṇāni.

sn41.8:5.12.pli: Cattāro pañhā, cattāro uddesā, cattāri veyyākaraṇāni.

sn41.8:5.13.pli: Pañca pañhā, pañca uddesā, pañca veyyākaraṇāni.

sn41.8:5.14.pli: Cha pañhā, cha uddesā, cha veyyākaraṇāni.

sn41.8:5.15.pli: Satta pañhā, satta uddesā, satta veyyākaraṇāni.

sn41.8:5.16.pli: Aṭṭha pañhā, aṭṭha uddesā, aṭṭha veyyākaraṇāni.

sn41.8:5.17.pli: Nava pañhā, nava uddesā, nava veyyākaraṇāni.

sn41.8:5.18.pli: Dasa pañhā, dasa uddesā, dasa veyyākaraṇānī”ti.

sn41.8:5.19.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ ime dasa sahadhammike pañhe āpucchitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmīti.
sn41.8:5.19.eng: Then Citta got up from his seat and left without asking the Jain Ñātika these ten legitimate questions.

sn41.9:1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena acelo kassapo macchikāsaṇḍaṃ anuppatto hoti cittassa gahapatino purāṇagihisahāyo.
sn41.9:1.1.eng: Now at that time the naked ascetic Kassapa, an old friend of Citta in the lay life, had arrived at Macchikāsaṇḍa.

sn41.9:1.2.pli: Assosi kho citto gahapati: “acelo kira kassapo macchikāsaṇḍaṃ anuppatto amhākaṃ purāṇagihisahāyo”ti.
sn41.9:1.2.eng: Citta the householder heard that he had arrived.

sn41.9:1.3.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati yena acelo kassapo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā acelena kassapena saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn41.9:1.3.eng: So he went up to him, and they exchanged greetings.

sn41.9:1.4.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho citto gahapati acelaṃ kassapaṃ etadavoca:
sn41.9:1.4.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the naked ascetic Kassapa,

sn41.9:1.5.eng: “Honorable Kassapa, how long has it been since you went forth?”

sn41.9:1.7.pli: “Imehi pana te, bhante, tiṃsamattehi vassehi atthi koci uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti?
sn41.9:1.7.eng: “But sir, in these thirty years have you achieved any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a comfortable meditation?”

sn41.9:1.8.pli: “Imehi kho me, gahapati, tiṃsamattehi vassehi pabbajitassa natthi koci uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro, aññatra naggeyyā ca muṇḍeyyā ca pāvaḷanipphoṭanāya cā”ti.
sn41.9:1.8.eng: “I have no such achievement, householder, only nudity, baldness, and pokes in the buttocks.”

sn41.9:1.9.pli: Evaṃ vutte, citto gahapati acelaṃ kassapaṃ etadavoca:

sn41.9:1.11.pli: Dhammassa svākkhātatā yatra hi nāma tiṃsamattehi vassehi na koci uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato abhavissa phāsuvihāro, aññatra naggeyyā ca muṇḍeyyā ca pāvaḷanipphoṭanāya cā”ti.
sn41.9:1.11.eng: how well explained the teaching is. For in thirty years you have achieved no superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, no comfortable meditation, only nudity, baldness, and pokes in the buttocks.”

sn41.9:2.1.eng: “But householder, how long have you been a lay follower?”

sn41.9:2.2.pli: “Mayhampi kho pana, bhante, tiṃsamattāni vassāni upāsakattaṃ upagatassā”ti.

sn41.9:2.3.pli: “Imehi pana te, gahapati, tiṃsamattehi vassehi atthi koci uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti?
sn41.9:2.3.eng: “But householder, in these thirty years have you achieved any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a comfortable meditation?”

sn41.9:2.5.pli: Ahañhi, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāmi, vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn41.9:2.5.eng: For whenever I want, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn41.9:2.6.pli: Ahañhi, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāmi, vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā … dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn41.9:2.6.eng: And whenever I want, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled … I enter and remain in the second absorption.

sn41.9:2.7.pli: Ahañhi, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāmi, pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn41.9:2.7.eng: And whenever I want, with the fading away of rapture … I enter and remain in the third absorption.

sn41.9:2.8.pli: Ahañhi, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāmi, sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn41.9:2.8.eng: And whenever I want, giving up pleasure and pain … I enter and remain in the fourth absorption.

sn41.9:2.9.pli: Sace kho panāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavato paṭhamataraṃ kālaṃ kareyyaṃ, anacchariyaṃ kho panetaṃ yaṃ maṃ bhagavā evaṃ byākareyya:
sn41.9:2.9.eng: If I pass away before the Buddha, it would be no wonder if the Buddha declares of me:

sn41.9:2.10.pli: ‘natthi taṃ saṃyojanaṃ yena saṃyojanena saṃyutto citto gahapati puna imaṃ lokaṃ āgaccheyyā’”ti.
sn41.9:2.10.eng: ‘The householder Citta is bound by no fetter that might return him to this world.’”

sn41.9:2.11.pli: Evaṃ vutte, acelo kassapo cittaṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca:
sn41.9:2.11.eng: When this was said, Kassapa said to Citta,

sn41.9:2.13.pli: Dhammassa svākkhātatā, yatra hi nāma gihī odātavasano evarūpaṃ uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesaṃ adhigamissati phāsuvihāraṃ.
sn41.9:2.13.eng: how well explained the teaching is. For a white-clothed layperson can achieve such a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a comfortable meditation.

sn41.9:2.14.pli: Labheyyāhaṃ, gahapati, imasmiṃ dhammavinaye pabbajjaṃ, labheyyaṃ upasampadan”ti.
sn41.9:2.14.eng: Householder, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in this teaching and training?”

sn41.9:3.1.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati acelaṃ kassapaṃ ādāya yena therā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā there bhikkhū etadavoca:
sn41.9:3.1.eng: Then Citta the householder took the naked ascetic Kassapa to see the senior mendicants, and said to them:

sn41.9:3.2.eng: “Sirs, this is the naked ascetic Kassapa, who in lay life was an old friend of mine.

sn41.9:3.3.eng: May the senior monks give him the going forth, the ordination.

sn41.9:3.4.eng: I’ll make sure that he’s provided with robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.”

sn41.9:3.5.pli: Alattha kho acelo kassapo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye pabbajjaṃ, alattha upasampadaṃ.
sn41.9:3.5.eng: And the naked ascetic Kassapa received the going forth, the ordination in this teaching and training.

sn41.9:3.6.pli: Acirūpasampanno ca panāyasmā kassapo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
sn41.9:3.6.eng: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Kassapa, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

sn41.9:3.7.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
sn41.9:3.7.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

sn41.9:3.8.pli: Aññataro ca panāyasmā kassapo arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn41.9:3.8.eng: And Venerable Kassapa became one of the perfected.

sn42.1:1.2.pli: Atha kho caṇḍo gāmaṇi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho caṇḍo gāmaṇi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn42.1:1.2.eng: Then the chief named Fury went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn42.1:1.3.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo yena midhekacco caṇḍo caṇḍotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
sn42.1:1.3.eng: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some people are regarded as furious,

sn42.1:1.4.pli: Ko pana, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo yena midhekacco sorato soratotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchatī”ti?
sn42.1:1.4.eng: while others are regarded as gentle?”

sn42.1:1.5.eng: “Take someone who hasn’t given up greed.

sn42.1:1.6.pli: Rāgassa appahīnattā pare kopenti, parehi kopiyamāno kopaṃ pātukaroti.
sn42.1:1.6.eng: So they get annoyed by others, and they show it.

sn42.1:1.9.pli: Dosassa appahīnattā pare kopenti, parehi kopiyamāno kopaṃ pātukaroti.
sn42.1:1.9.eng: So they get annoyed by others, and they show it.

sn42.1:1.12.pli: Mohassa appahīnattā pare kopenti, parehi kopiyamāno kopaṃ pātukaroti.
sn42.1:1.12.eng: So they get annoyed by others, and they show it.

sn42.1:1.14.pli: Ayaṃ kho, gāmaṇi, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo yena midhekacco caṇḍo caṇḍotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
sn42.1:1.14.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why some people are regarded as furious.

sn42.1:2.1.pli: Idha pana, gāmaṇi, ekaccassa rāgo pahīno hoti.
sn42.1:2.1.eng: But take someone who has given up greed.

sn42.1:2.2.pli: Rāgassa pahīnattā pare na kopenti, parehi kopiyamāno kopaṃ na pātukaroti.
sn42.1:2.2.eng: So they don’t get annoyed by others, and don’t show it.

sn42.1:2.5.pli: Dosassa pahīnattā pare na kopenti, parehi kopiyamāno kopaṃ na pātukaroti.
sn42.1:2.5.eng: So they don’t get annoyed by others, and don’t show it.

sn42.1:2.8.pli: Mohassa pahīnattā pare na kopenti, parehi kopiyamāno kopaṃ na pātukaroti.
sn42.1:2.8.eng: So they don’t get annoyed by others, and don’t show it.

sn42.1:2.10.pli: Ayaṃ kho, gāmaṇi, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yena midhekacco sorato soratotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchatī”ti.
sn42.1:2.10.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why some people are regarded as gentle.”

sn42.1:3.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, caṇḍo gāmaṇi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn42.1:3.1.eng: When he said this, the chief named Fury said to the Buddha,

sn42.1:3.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
sn42.1:3.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.

sn42.1:3.4.pli: Esāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
sn42.1:3.4.eng: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

sn42.1:3.5.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
sn42.1:3.5.eng: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
